<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

<meta property="og:likes" content="13"/>
<meta property="og:readtime" content="9"/>
<meta property="og:views" content="42,413"/>
<meta property="og:date_created" content="April 9, 2021 at 12:00 PM"/>
<meta property="og:post_length" content="2420"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Malware"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Threat Research"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Chris Navarrete"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Yanhui Jia"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/chris-navarrete/"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/yanhui-jia/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta name="post_tags" content="C2,Command and Control,Emotet,exploit"/>
<meta property="og:post_image" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Malware-r3d2.png"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Emotet Command and Control Case Study","name":"Emotet Command and Control Case Study","description":"We provide a step-by-step technical analysis of Emotet command and control, based on observations from before Emotet threat actors were disrupted.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/emotet-command-and-control\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/emotet-command-and-control\/","datePublished":"April 9, 2021","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nOn March 8, 2021, Unit 42 published \u201cAttack Chain Overview: Emotet in December 2020 and January 2021.\u201d Based on that analysis, the updated version of Emotet talks to different command and control (C2) servers for data exfiltration or to implement further attacks. We observed attackers taking advantage of a sophisticated evasion technique and encryption algorithm to communicate with C2 servers in order to probe the victim's network environment and processes, allowing attackers to steal a user\u2019s sensitive information or drop a new payload.\r\n\r\nIn this blog, we provide a step-by-step technical analysis, beginning from where the main logic starts, covering the encryption mechanisms and ending when the C2 data is exfiltrated through HTTP protocol to the C2 server.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks Next-Generation Firewall customers are protected from Emotet with Threat Prevention and WildFire security subscriptions. Customers are also protected with Cortex XDR.\r\nTechnical Analysis\r\nThis analysis will use custom function names (i.e.,\u00a0collect_process_data) that replace the regular IDA Pro's function format (i.e.,\u00a0sub_*) and will assume a 32-bit (x86) DLL executable with an image base address of\u00a00x2E1000. The user can refer to the following image that contains function offsets, names and custom names for easy reference.\r\n\r\nNOTE: Sub-functions used are not listed, since these can be easily located from the presented function offsets.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118305\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 1. IDA\u2019s functions reference information.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe present analysis begins from the entry point function\u00a0c2_logic_ep\u00a0(sub_2E2C63).\r\nEncryption API Functions\r\nThis malware uses two main functions: encryption_functions_one and\u00a0 encryption_functions_two. Both functions makes use of Microsoft's Base Cryptography\u00a0(CryptoAPI). The following section includes the properties used and actions performed by these crypto functions during the malware execution.\r\n\r\n \tCryptAcquireContextW\u00a0- Uses a\u00a0PROV_DH_SCHANNEL\u00a0as provider type (0x18). The\u00a0CRYPT_VERIFYCONTEXT\u00a0and\u00a0CRYPT_SILENT\u00a0flags are\u00a0combined with a bitwise-OR operation (0xf0000040) to make sure that no user interface (UI) is displayed to the user.\r\n \tCryptDecodeObjectEx\u00a0- Uses a message encoding type\u00a0X509_ASN_ENCODING\u00a0and\u00a0PKCS_7_ASN_ENCODING\u00a0that are combined with a bitwise-OR operation\u00a0(0x10001), a structure type\u00a0X509_BASIC_CONSTRAINTS\u00a0(0x13) and a total of\u00a00x6a\u00a0bytes that are going to be decoded.\r\n \tCryptImportKey\u00a0- Imports a key-blob of\u00a00x74\u00a0in size (bytes) and type\u00a0PUBLICKEYBLOB\u00a0(0x6) with a\u00a0CUR_BLOB_VERSION\u00a0(0x2) version.\r\n \tCryptGenKey\u00a0- Uses an\u00a0ALG_ID\u00a0value that is set to\u00a0CALG_AES_128\u00a0(0x0000660e) and generates a 128-bit AES session key.\r\n \tCryptCreateHash\u00a0- Uses an\u00a0ALG_ID\u00a0value that is set to\u00a0CALG_SHA\u00a0(0x00008004), which, as the the name suggests, sets the\u00a0SHA\u00a0hashing algorithm.\r\n \tCryptDuplicateHash\u00a0- Receives a handle to the hash to be duplicated.\r\n \tCryptEncrypt\u00a0- This function receives two main parameters: a handle to the encryption key generated by the CryptGenKey function and a handle to a hash object generated by CryptCreateHash. This value will be used after encryption by calling the\u00a0CryptEncrypt\u00a0function and passing as a parameter the pointer to the C2 data.\r\n \tCryptExportKey\u00a0- Uses a\u00a0SIMPLEBLOB\u00a0(0x1) type and\u00a0CRYPT_OAEP\u00a0(0x00000040) as a flag. The pointer to the buffer where the key-blob is exported is part of the malware's C2 data.\r\n \tCryptGetHashParam\u00a0- As in the case of the\u00a0CryptExportKey\u00a0function, the destination pointer is part of the malware's C2 data.\r\n \tCryptDestroyHash\u00a0- As its name implies, destroys the given hash.\r\n\r\nMachine ID Generation and Length Checking\r\nThe\u00a0generate_machine_id\u00a0function, as its name states, is in charge of generating a machine identifier for the infected computer. The method used to generate the machine identifier is by making a call to the\u00a0_snprintf\u00a0function, which uses the format\u00a0string %s_%08X\u00a0to concatenate the value generated by\u00a0GetComputerNameA\u00a0and\u00a0GetVolumeInformationW. In the particular case of the test machine used in this analysis, the resulting value is ANANDAXPC_58F2C41B.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118307\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"823\"] Figure 2. Function call to generate a machine identifier (machine-ID value).[\/caption]\r\n\r\nOnce the\u00a0machine-id\u00a0is generated, a length-check verification is also generated. This is achieved by calling the\u00a0\"lstrlen\"\u00a0function wrapper\u00a0gen_machine_id_length\u00a0and passing as a parameter the returning value from the previous function call. For the case of the testing machine, the resulting length was \"12\", and such value will reside in a particular stack variable since it will be used as part of the\u00a0C2 data. Subsequently, a new function call is made to the\u00a0write_GoR\u00a0function. Its original purpose is unknown, however, based on the analysis and how the returning value (0x16F87C) is used. It\u2019s presumably a delimiter, since it is located at the end of the\u00a0C2 data.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118309\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"817\"] Figure 3 . Function call to generate C2 data delimiter.[\/caption]\r\nOperating System Data Collection\r\nPart of the exfiltrated data also includes\u00a0OS information,\u00a0and this is achieved by calling the\u00a0collect_os_data function.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118311\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"819\"] Figure 4. Function call to collect OS information.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThis function makes calls\u00a0to RtlGetVersion, which stores data inside of an\u00a0OSVERSIONINFOW\u00a0structure, and\u00a0GetNativeSystemInfo\u00a0performs the same by saving its data inside a\u00a0SYSTEM_INFO\u00a0structure.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118313\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"820\"] Figure 5. OSVERSIONINFOW and SYSTEM_INFO structures filled up by API calls.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nOnce the data structures are populated, specific data is fetched by the instructions located at these offsets:\u00a00x2EC3DB (Ret value),\u00a00x2EC440 (MajorVersion),\u00a00x2EC3DB,\u00a00x2EC3D0 (MinorVersion) and\u00a00x2EC45A (Architecture|PROCESSOR_ARCHITECTURE_INTEL).\r\n\r\nThe returning value is computed by adding and multiplying against fixed values:\u00a0MajorVersion,\u00a0MinorVersion,\u00a0Architecture and the returning value (0x1) of the\u00a0RtlGetNtProductType call, which is a symbolic constant (NtProductWinNT) of the NT_PRODUCT_TYPE enumeration data type. The following Python code simulates the logic that generates such value.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118315\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"810\"] Figure 6. Python proof of concept (PoC) emulating the OS data generation algorithm.[\/caption]\r\nRemote Desktop Services Session Information Collection\r\nMore calls are performed, including the one to\u00a0GetCurrentProcessId, which retrieves the process identifier for the current process, and the returning value is passed to the ProcessIdToSessionId\u00a0function as parameter. According to the MSDN description, the\u00a0ProcessIdToSessionId function \"retrieves the Remote Desktop Services session associated with a specified process.\" The returning value of this function indicates the Terminal Services session the current process is running on.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118317\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 7. Function call to retrieve the Terminal Service session identifier.[\/caption]\r\nProcess Scanning and C2 Data Collection\r\nThis function collects active running processes on the system by the execution of the traditional method of calling the\u00a0CreateToolhelp32Snapshot,\u00a0Process32FirstW,\u00a0GetCurrentProcessId\u00a0and Process32NextW functions. Before entering to this function, the instruction at offset\u00a00x2E4715\u00a0loads the address of a local variable in the EAX\u00a0register and pushed onto the stack. This variable will contain a pointer generated by a call to the RtAllocateHeap function that will eventually receive the process data information.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118319\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"819\"] Figure 8. Function call to generate and initialize values with process data.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThis function also makes calls to the sub-function named\u00a0copy_collected_data_parent. During its execution, it generates a new memory section made by a call to the\u00a0RtlAllocateHeap\u00a0function, and some subsequent calls to the\u00a0memcpy\u00a0wrapper function to copy collected C2 data to the new allocated section.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118321\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"815\"] Figure 9. Function call that collects and initializes values with C2 data.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe next function to call is\u00a0HTTP_LAUNCHER, which contains sub-functions that provide web capability, among other tasks. At this point in time, the variables are initialized with the corresponding return values from the previously executed functions. The following ASCII dump shows the variable addresses, the related data and information about which function, or instruction offset, provided the given data.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118323\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 10. Stack-snapshot including collected data and the data generation functions references.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe next step is a call to the\u00a0c2_data_write\u00a0function, which calls the\u00a0write_collected_data\u00a0sub-function and passes as parameters two values:\r\n\r\n \tA pointer to the\u00a0C2 data (0x2EAC3E).\r\n \tThe returning value (address) of a new memory allocation generated by a call to the\u00a0RtlAllocateHeap\u00a0function located at offset\u00a00x2F989B.\r\n\r\nThis newly generated data passes through an algorithm, which in addition to writing (at offset\u00a00x2FA830) also modifies certain bytes (at offset\u00a00x2FA6DE) of the\u00a0C2 data, especially some filename extensions.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118325\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"812\"] Figure 11. Function calls that write collected data in memory.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nOnce the data is collected, a call to\u00a0write_c2_data_zero\u00a0is made, which will allocate additional memory by calling the AllocateHeap (0x2E99DC) function. This function will eventually be called twice, and it will call more sub-functions in where the instructions at offset\u00a00x2F362A\u00a0of\u00a0the write_c2_data_one\u00a0function will generate two DWORD values:\u00a00x1, which is a fixed value, and\u00a00x132,\u00a0which is the length of the\u00a0C2 data. The next step is a call to\u00a0copy_c2_data\u00a0(a wrapper to\u00a0memcpy\u00a0at offset\u00a00x2F794C) function, which copies the\u00a0C2 data\u00a0to a new location next to the two values mentioned earlier.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118327\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"824\"] Figure 12. Function calls that perform intermediary C2 data copying.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe next sequential function execution is a call to\u00a0CryptDuplicateHash. After that, a call to\u00a0copy_binary_data\u00a0is made, which makes a final C2 data copy to a new memory allocation. This location will contain the last\u00a0C2 data\u00a0before being encrypted by the\u00a0CryptEncrypt\u00a0function, as will be performed in subsequent steps.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118329\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"815\"] Figure 13. Function calls that make a final copy of unencrypted C2 data.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe following picture shows the buffer with its related values and description highlighted with different colors for easy reference.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118331\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"565\"] Figure 14. In-memory byte offsets and sizes, including individual descriptions.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe next call is to the\u00a0CryptEncrypt\u00a0function wrapper, which will reach the\u00a0real\u00a0API function via an indirect call to\u00a0the EAX\u00a0register located at offset\u00a00x2F0AD4.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118333\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"818\"] Figure 15. Function call to CryptEncrypt to encrypt C2 data.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe following picture shows the\u00a0before\u00a0and\u00a0after\u00a0encryption status of the\u00a0C2 data.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118335\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"668\"] Figure 16. Before and after encryption status of C2 data.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nOnce the\u00a0C2 data\u00a0is encrypted, the following step is to export the current encryption key by calling the\u00a0CryptExportKey\u00a0function at offset\u00a00x2EFF2C.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118337\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"812\"] Figure 17. Function call to CryptExportKey wrapper.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAfter exporting the key, a loop located at offset\u00a00x2EFF41\u00a0has an instruction at offset\u00a00x2EFF43 that\u00a0writes into C2 data\u00a00x60\u00a0bytes of the exported key.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118339\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"819\"] Figure 18. Write loop to populate exported crypto key data.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nNow, a call to the API function\u00a0CryptGetHashParam\u00a0is made with a parameter that contains a pointer to\u00a0CryptDestroyHash\u00a0that will write\u00a020\u00a0bytes of the generated hash into the\u00a0C2 data.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118341\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"825\"] Figure 19. Function call to CryptGetHashParam.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe following image shows how the final C2 data is stored in memory.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118343\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"456\"] Figure 20. In-memory byte inclusion of Exported Key, Hash Value and Encrypted C2 data.[\/caption]\r\nC2 Exfiltration: HTTP Post Request Generation\r\nAt this stage, the C2 data containing\u00a0Exported Key,\u00a0Hash Value, and\u00a0Encrypted C2 data\u00a0are done. Thus, the last stage is the completion of the data exfiltration. The following steps prepare the required data (e.g., IP address, HTTP form structure and values, etc.).\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118345\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"819\"] Figure 21. Function calls to fulfill the first half of HTTP requirements before data exfiltration.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAt this point, subsequent function calls are performed to generate the binary data that will be included within the HTTP form. The following section will describe the detailed steps that lead to such encrypted data and its exfiltration to the C2 server.\r\n\r\nThis step consists of copying the\u00a0C2 data\u00a0(bytes) to the web form. This is achieved by the execution of the copy_c2_data sub-function. This function will generate a binary MIME attachment of the \"application\/octet-stream\" content type with the input data to be suitable for binary transfer.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118347\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"816\"] Figure 22. Function calls to copy binary data to the web form.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAt this stage, the final payload is preparing the environment to submit information to the C2 server. To do so, it executes function calls to retrieve the required data to finally perform the HTTP request.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118349\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"818\"] Figure 23. Function calls to fulfill the second half of HTTP requirements before data exfiltration.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAs can be seen in the function call list, the HttpSendRequestW() API function is used to send the data to the server. This function allows the sender to exceed the amount of data that is normally sent by HTTP clients.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_118351\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"602\"] Figure 24. Wireshark capture showing POST request including Exported Key, Hash Value and Encrypted C2 data.[\/caption]\r\nConclusion\r\nEmotet was active in the wild for several years before a coordinated law enforcement campaign shut down its infrastructure in late January 2021. Its attack tactics and techniques had evolved over time, and the attack chain is very mature and sophisticated, which makes it a good case study for security researchers. This research provides an example of Emotet C2 communication, including C2 server IP selection and data encryption, so we can better understand how Emotet malware utilizes this sophisticated technique to evade security production detection.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are protected from this kind of attack by the following:\r\n\r\n \tThreat Prevention signatures 21201, 21185 and 21167 identify HTTP C2 requests attempting to download the new payload and post sensitive info.\r\n \tWildFire and Cortex XDR identify and block Emotet and its droppers.\r\n\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nSamples\r\n2cb81a1a59df4a4fd222fbcb946db3d653185c2e79cf4d3365b430b1988d485f\r\nDroppers\r\nbbb9c1b98ec307a5e84095cf491f7475964a698c90b48a9d43490a05b6ba0a79\r\nbd1e56637bd0fe213c2c58d6bd4e6e3693416ec2f90ea29f0c68a0b91815d91a\r\nURLs\r\nhttp:\/\/allcannabismeds[.]com\/unraid-map\/ZZm6\/\r\nhttp:\/\/giannaspsychicstudio[.]com\/cgi-bin\/PP\/\r\nhttp:\/\/ienglishabc[.]com\/cow\/JH\/\r\nhttp:\/\/abrillofurniture[.]com\/bph-nclex-wygq4\/a7nBfhs\/\r\nhttps:\/\/etkindedektiflik[.]com\/pcie-speed\/U\/\r\nhttps:\/\/vstsample[.]com\/wp-includes\/7eXeI\/\r\nhttp:\/\/ezi-pos[.]com\/categoryl\/x\/\r\nIPs\r\n5.2.136[.]90\r\n161.49.84[.]2\r\n70.32.89[.]105\r\n190.247.139[.]101\r\n138.197.99[.]250\r\n152.170.79[.]100\r\n190.55.186[.]229\r\n132.248.38[.]158\r\n110.172.180[.]180\r\n37.46.129[.]215\r\n203.157.152[.]9\r\n157.245.145[.]87\r\n\r\n&nbsp;","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/06\/14_Cybercrime_Category_1920x900-300x300.jpg","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Chris <script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</head>
<body class="post-template-default single single-post postid-118300 single-format-standard no-sidebar">

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-41" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-41"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/atoms/">ATOMs</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

	<div class="ab__share" id="shareDropdown" role="button" aria-expanded="false">
	<a href="#" role="link" title="Click here to share" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:share" class="">Share<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/down-arrow.svg" alt="Down arrow"></a><ul class="share-dropdown" role="menu">
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="#" class="copy-url" id="copyUrl" data-url="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/emotet-command-and-control/" role="link" title="Copy link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:share:link"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-share-link.svg" alt="Link Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="mailto:?subject=Emotet%20Command%20and%20Control%20Case%20Study&#038;body=Check%20out%20this%20article%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Femotet-command-and-control%2F" role="link" title="Share in email" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:share:email"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-sms.svg" alt="Link Email"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Femotet-command-and-control%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Facebook" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:share:facebook"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-fb-share.svg" alt="Facebook Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Femotet-command-and-control%2F&#038;title=Emotet%20Command%20and%20Control%20Case%20Study" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in LinkedIn" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:share:linkedin"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-linkedin-share.svg" alt="LinkedIn Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Femotet-command-and-control%2F&#038;text=Emotet%20Command%20and%20Control%20Case%20Study" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Twitter" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:share:twitter"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-twitter-share.svg" alt="Twitter Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="//www.reddit.com/submit?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Femotet-command-and-control%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Reddit" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:share:reddit"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-reddit-share.svg" alt="Reddit Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://mastodon.social/share?text=Emotet%20Command%20and%20Control%20Case%20Study%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Femotet-command-and-control%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Mastodon" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:share:mastodon"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-mastodon-share.svg" alt="Mastodon Icon"></a>
				</li>
	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/emotet-command-and-control/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-118300-_gu6uq7cfnjyn"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>On March 8, 2021, Unit 42 published “<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/attack-chain-overview-emotet-in-december-2020-and-january-2021/">Attack Chain Overview: Emotet in December 2020 and January 2021</a>.” Based on that analysis, the updated version of Emotet talks to different command and control (C2) servers for data exfiltration or to implement further attacks. We observed attackers taking advantage of a sophisticated evasion technique and encryption algorithm to communicate with C2 servers in order to probe the victim's network environment and processes, allowing attackers to steal a user’s sensitive information or drop a new payload.</p>
<p>In this blog, we provide a step-by-step technical analysis, beginning from where the main logic starts, covering the encryption mechanisms and ending when the C2 data is exfiltrated through HTTP protocol to the C2 server.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall">Palo Alto Networks Next-Generation Firewall</a> customers are protected from Emotet with <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/subscriptions/threat-prevention">Threat Prevention</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire">WildFire</a> security subscriptions. Customers are also protected with <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr">Cortex XDR</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-118300-_vx7fs63eeha7"></a>Technical Analysis</h2>
<p>This analysis will use custom function names (i.e., <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">collect_process_data</span>) that replace the regular IDA Pro's function format (i.e., sub_*) and will assume a 32-bit (x86) DLL executable with an image base address of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0x2E1000</span>. The user can refer to the following image that contains function offsets, names and custom names for easy reference.</p>
<p><strong>NOTE:</strong> Sub-functions used are not listed, since these can be easily located from the presented function offsets.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118305" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118305" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118305 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-31.png" alt="Figure 1. IDA’s functions reference information." width="900" height="500" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118305" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. IDA’s functions reference information.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The present analysis begins from the entry point function c2_logic_ep (sub_2E2C63).</p>
<h4><a id="post-118300-_cvgoax9mxjll"></a>Encryption API Functions</h4>
<p>This malware uses two main functions: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">encryption_functions_one</span> and  <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">encryption_functions_two</span>. Both functions makes use of Microsoft's Base Cryptography (CryptoAPI). The following section includes the properties used and actions performed by these crypto functions during the malware execution.</p>
<ul>
<li><em>CryptAcquireContextW</em> - Uses a <strong>PROV_DH_SCHANNEL</strong> as provider type (<strong>0x18</strong>). The <strong>CRYPT_VERIFYCONTEXT</strong> and <strong>CRYPT_SILENT</strong> flags are combined with a bitwise-<strong>OR</strong> operation (<strong>0xf0000040</strong>) to make sure that no user interface (UI) is displayed to the user.</li>
<li><em>CryptDecodeObjectEx</em> - Uses a message encoding type <strong>X509_ASN_ENCODING</strong> and <strong>PKCS_7_ASN_ENCODING</strong> that are combined with a bitwise-<strong>OR</strong> operation (<strong>0x10001</strong>), a structure type <strong>X509_BASIC_CONSTRAINTS</strong> (<strong>0x13</strong>) and a total of <strong>0x6a</strong> bytes that are going to be decoded.</li>
<li><em>CryptImportKey</em> - Imports a key-blob of <strong>0x74</strong> in size (bytes) and type <strong>PUBLICKEYBLOB</strong> (<strong>0x6</strong>) with a <strong>CUR_BLOB_VERSION</strong> (<strong>0x2</strong>) version.</li>
<li><em>CryptGenKey</em> - Uses an <strong>ALG_ID</strong> value that is set to <strong>CALG_AES_128</strong> (<strong>0x0000660e</strong>) and generates a 128-bit AES session key.</li>
<li><em>CryptCreateHash</em> - Uses an <strong>ALG_ID</strong> value that is set to <strong>CALG_SHA</strong> (<strong>0x00008004</strong>), which, as the the name suggests, sets the SHA hashing algorithm.</li>
<li><em>CryptDuplicateHash</em> - Receives a handle to the hash to be duplicated.</li>
<li><em>CryptEncrypt</em> - This function receives two main parameters: a handle to the encryption key generated by the <em>CryptGenKey</em> function and a handle to a hash object generated by <em>CryptCreateHash</em>. This value will be used after encryption by calling the <em>CryptEncrypt</em> function and passing as a parameter the pointer to the C2 data.</li>
<li><em>CryptExportKey</em> - Uses a <strong>SIMPLEBLOB</strong> (<strong>0x1</strong>) type and <strong>CRYPT_OAEP</strong> (<strong>0x00000040</strong>) as a flag. The pointer to the buffer where the key-blob is exported is part of the malware's C2 data.</li>
<li><em>CryptGetHashParam</em> - As in the case of the <em>CryptExportKey</em> function, the destination pointer is part of the malware's C2 data.</li>
<li><em>CryptDestroyHash</em> - As its name implies, destroys the given hash.</li>
</ul>
<h4><a id="post-118300-_cbfjbot2ymkq"></a>Machine ID Generation and Length Checking</h4>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">generate_machine_id</span> function, as its name states, is in charge of generating a machine identifier for the infected computer. The method used to generate the machine identifier is by making a call to the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">_snprintf</span> function, which uses the format string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%s_%08X</span> to concatenate the value generated by <em>GetComputerNameA</em> and <em>GetVolumeInformationW</em>. In the particular case of the test machine used in this analysis, the resulting value is <strong>ANANDAXPC_58F2C41B</strong>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118307" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118307" style="width: 823px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118307 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-32.png" alt="Figure 2. Function call to generate a machine identifier (machine-ID value)." width="823" height="178" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118307" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Function call to generate a machine identifier (machine-ID value).</figcaption></figure>
<p>Once the machine-id is generated, a length-check verification is also generated. This is achieved by calling the "lstrlen" function wrapper <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">gen_machine_id_length</span> and passing as a parameter the returning value from the previous function call. For the case of the testing machine, the resulting length was "<strong>12</strong>", and such value will reside in a particular stack variable since it will be used as part of the C2 data. Subsequently, a new function call is made to the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">write_GoR</span> function. Its original purpose is unknown, however, based on the analysis and how the returning value (<strong>0x16F87C</strong>) is used. It’s presumably a delimiter, since it is located at the end of the C2 data.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118309" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118309" style="width: 817px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118309 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-33.png" alt="Figure 3 . Function call to generate C2 data delimiter." width="817" height="122" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118309" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3 . Function call to generate C2 data delimiter.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-118300-_xifq7kbepdcx"></a>Operating System Data Collection</h4>
<p>Part of the exfiltrated data also includes <strong>OS information,</strong> and this is achieved by calling the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">collect_os_data</span> function.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118311" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118311" style="width: 819px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118311 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-34.png" alt="Figure 4. Function call to collect OS information." width="819" height="110" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118311" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Function call to collect OS information.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This function makes calls to <em>RtlGetVersion,</em> which stores data inside of an <em>OSVERSIONINFOW</em> structure, and <em>GetNativeSystemInfo</em> performs the same by saving its data inside a <em>SYSTEM_INFO</em> structure.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118313" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118313" style="width: 820px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118313 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-35.png" alt="Figure 5. OSVERSIONINFOW and SYSTEM_INFO structures filled up by API calls." width="820" height="408" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118313" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. OSVERSIONINFOW and SYSTEM_INFO structures filled up by API calls.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Once the data structures are populated, specific data is fetched by the instructions located at these offsets: 0x2EC3DB (<em>Ret value</em>), 0x2EC440 (<em>MajorVersion</em>), 0x2EC3DB, 0x2EC3D0 (<em>MinorVersion</em>) and 0x2EC45A (<em>Architecture|PROCESSOR_ARCHITECTURE_INTEL</em>).</p>
<p>The returning value is computed by adding and multiplying against fixed values: <em>MajorVersion</em>, <em>MinorVersion</em>, <em>Architecture</em> and the returning value (0x1) of the <em>RtlGetNtProductType </em>call, which is a symbolic constant (<em>NtProductWinNT) </em>of the NT_PRODUCT_TYPE enumeration data type. The following Python code simulates the logic that generates such value.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118315" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118315" style="width: 810px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118315 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-36.png" alt="Figure 6. Python proof of concept (PoC) emulating the OS data generation algorithm." width="810" height="248" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118315" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Python proof of concept (PoC) emulating the OS data generation algorithm.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-118300-_raoo96lhvhpz"></a>Remote Desktop Services Session Information Collection</h4>
<p>More calls are performed, including the one to <em>GetCurrentProcessId</em>, which retrieves the process identifier for the current process, and the returning value is passed to the <em>ProcessIdToSessionId</em> function as parameter. According to the <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/processthreadsapi/nf-processthreadsapi-processidtosessionid">MSDN description</a>, the <em>ProcessIdToSessionId </em>function "retrieves the Remote Desktop Services session associated with a specified process." The returning value of this function indicates the Terminal Services session the current process is running on.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118317" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118317" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118317 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-37.png" alt="Figure 7. Function call to retrieve the Terminal Service session identifier." width="900" height="114" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118317" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Function call to retrieve the Terminal Service session identifier.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-118300-_qari62uuxtwq"></a>Process Scanning and C2 Data Collection</h4>
<p>This function collects active running processes on the system by the execution of the traditional method of calling the <em>CreateToolhelp32Snapshot</em>, <em>Process32FirstW</em>, <em>GetCurrentProcessId</em> and <em>Process32NextW</em> functions. Before entering to this function, the instruction at offset 0x2E4715 loads the address of a local variable in the EAX register and pushed onto the stack. This variable will contain a pointer generated by a call to the <em>RtAllocateHeap</em> function that will eventually receive the process data information.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118319" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118319" style="width: 819px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118319 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-38.png" alt="Figure 8. Function call to generate and initialize values with process data." width="819" height="234" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118319" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Function call to generate and initialize values with process data.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This function also makes calls to the sub-function named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">copy_collected_data_parent</span>. During its execution, it generates a new memory section made by a call to the <em>RtlAllocateHeap</em> function, and some subsequent calls to the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">memcpy</span> wrapper function to copy collected C2 data to the new allocated section.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118321" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118321" style="width: 815px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118321 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-39.png" alt="Figure 9. Function call that collects and initializes values with C2 data." width="815" height="236" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118321" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Function call that collects and initializes values with C2 data.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The next function to call is <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">HTTP_LAUNCHER</span>, which contains sub-functions that provide web capability, among other tasks. At this point in time, the variables are initialized with the corresponding return values from the previously executed functions. The following ASCII dump shows the variable addresses, the related data and information about which function, or instruction offset, provided the given data.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118323" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118323" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118323 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-40.png" alt="Figure 10. Stack-snapshot including collected data and the data generation functions references." width="900" height="358" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118323" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Stack-snapshot including collected data and the data generation functions references.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The next step is a call to the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c2_data_write</span> function, which calls the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">write_collected_data</span> sub-function and passes as parameters two values:</p>
<ol>
<li>A pointer to the C2 data (0x2EAC3E).</li>
<li>The returning value (address) of a new memory allocation generated by a call to the <em>RtlAllocateHeap</em> function located at offset 0x2F989B.</li>
</ol>
<p>This newly generated data passes through an algorithm, which in addition to writing (at offset 0x2FA830) also modifies certain bytes (at offset 0x2FA6DE) of the C2 data, especially some filename extensions.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118325" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118325" style="width: 812px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118325 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-41.png" alt="Figure 11. Function calls that write collected data in memory." width="812" height="317" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118325" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Function calls that write collected data in memory.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Once the data is collected, a call to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">write_c2_data_zero</span> is made, which will allocate additional memory by calling the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AllocateHeap</span> (0x2E99DC) function. This function will eventually be called twice, and it will call more sub-functions in where the instructions at offset 0x2F362A of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">write_c2_data_one</span> function will generate two DWORD values: 0x1, which is a fixed value, and 0x132, which is the length of the C2 data. The next step is a call to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">copy_c2_data</span> (a wrapper to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">memcpy</span> at offset 0x2F794C) function, which copies the C2 data to a new location next to the two values mentioned earlier.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118327" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118327" style="width: 824px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118327 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-42.png" alt="Figure 12. Function calls that perform intermediary C2 data copying." width="824" height="187" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118327" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. Function calls that perform intermediary C2 data copying.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The next sequential function execution is a call to <em>CryptDuplicateHash</em>. After that, a call to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">copy_binary_data</span> is made, which makes a final C2 data copy to a new memory allocation. This location will contain the last C2 data before being encrypted by the <em>CryptEncrypt</em> function, as will be performed in subsequent steps.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118329" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118329" style="width: 815px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118329 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-43.png" alt="Figure 13. Function calls that make a final copy of unencrypted C2 data." width="815" height="174" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118329" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. Function calls that make a final copy of unencrypted C2 data.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The following picture shows the buffer with its related values and description highlighted with different colors for easy reference.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118331" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118331" style="width: 565px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118331 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-44.png" alt="Figure 14. In-memory byte offsets and sizes, including individual descriptions." width="565" height="248" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118331" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. In-memory byte offsets and sizes, including individual descriptions.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The next call is to the <em>CryptEncrypt</em> function wrapper, which will reach the real API function via an indirect call to the EAX register located at offset 0x2F0AD4.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118333" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118333" style="width: 818px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118333 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-45.png" alt="Figure 15. Function call to CryptEncrypt to encrypt C2 data." width="818" height="236" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118333" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 15. Function call to CryptEncrypt to encrypt C2 data.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The following picture shows the before and after encryption status of the C2 data.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118335" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118335" style="width: 668px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118335 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-46.png" alt="Figure 16. Before and after encryption status of C2 data." width="668" height="151" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118335" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 16. Before and after encryption status of C2 data.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Once the C2 data is encrypted, the following step is to export the current encryption key by calling the <em>CryptExportKey</em> function at offset 0x2EFF2C.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118337" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118337" style="width: 812px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118337 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-47.png" alt="Figure 17. Function call to CryptExportKey wrapper." width="812" height="254" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118337" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 17. Function call to CryptExportKey wrapper.</figcaption></figure>
<p>After exporting the key, a loop located at offset 0x2EFF41 has an instruction at offset 0x2EFF43 that writes into C2 data 0x60 bytes of the exported key.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118339" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118339" style="width: 819px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118339 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-48.png" alt="Figure 18. Write loop to populate exported crypto key data." width="819" height="171" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118339" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 18. Write loop to populate exported crypto key data.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Now, a call to the API function <em>CryptGetHashParam</em> is made with a parameter that contains a pointer to <em>CryptDestroyHash</em> that will write 20 bytes of the generated hash into the C2 data.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118341" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118341" style="width: 825px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118341 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-49.png" alt="Figure 19. Function call to CryptGetHashParam." width="825" height="87" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118341" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 19. Function call to CryptGetHashParam.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The following image shows how the final C2 data is stored in memory.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118343" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118343" style="width: 456px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118343 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-50.png" alt="Figure 20. In-memory byte inclusion of Exported Key, Hash Value and Encrypted C2 data." width="456" height="277" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118343" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 20. In-memory byte inclusion of Exported Key, Hash Value and Encrypted C2 data.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-118300-_n9wlfj95wipq"></a>C2 Exfiltration: HTTP Post Request Generation</h4>
<p>At this stage, the C2 data containing <strong>Exported Key</strong>, <strong>Hash Value</strong>, and <strong>Encrypted C2 data</strong> are done. Thus, the last stage is the completion of the data exfiltration. The following steps prepare the required data (e.g., IP address, HTTP form structure and values, etc.).</p>
<figure id="attachment_118345" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118345" style="width: 819px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118345 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-51.png" alt="Figure 21. Function calls to fulfill the first half of HTTP requirements before data exfiltration." width="819" height="103" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118345" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 21. Function calls to fulfill the first half of HTTP requirements before data exfiltration.</figcaption></figure>
<p>At this point, subsequent function calls are performed to generate the binary data that will be included within the HTTP form. The following section will describe the detailed steps that lead to such encrypted data and its exfiltration to the C2 server.</p>
<p>This step consists of copying the C2 data (bytes) to the web form. This is achieved by the execution of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">copy_c2_data</span> sub-function. This function will generate a binary <strong>MIME attachment</strong> of the "<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">application/octet-stream</span>" content type with the input data to be suitable for binary transfer.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118347" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118347" style="width: 816px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118347 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-52.png" alt="Figure 22. Function calls to copy binary data to the web form." width="816" height="419" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118347" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 22. Function calls to copy binary data to the web form.</figcaption></figure>
<p>At this stage, the final payload is preparing the environment to submit information to the C2 server. To do so, it executes function calls to retrieve the required data to finally perform the HTTP request.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118349" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118349" style="width: 818px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118349 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/word-image-53.png" alt="Figure 23. Function calls to fulfill the second half of HTTP requirements before data exfiltration." width="818" height="165" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118349" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 23. Function calls to fulfill the second half of HTTP requirements before data exfiltration.</figcaption></figure>
<p>As can be seen in the function call list, the HttpSendRequestW() API function is used to send the data to the server. This function allows the sender to exceed the amount of data that is normally sent by HTTP clients.</p>
<figure id="attachment_118351" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-118351" style="width: 602px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-118351 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/text-table-description-automatically-generated.jpeg" alt="Figure 24. Wireshark capture showing POST request including Exported Key, Hash Value and Encrypted C2 data." width="602" height="938" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-118351" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 24. Wireshark capture showing POST request including Exported Key, Hash Value and Encrypted C2 data.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-118300-_y0obp2yh27vo"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>Emotet was active in the wild for several years before a <a href="https://www.europol.europa.eu/newsroom/news/world%E2%80%99s-most-dangerous-malware-emotet-disrupted-through-global-action">coordinated law enforcement campaign</a> shut down its infrastructure in late January 2021. Its attack tactics and techniques had evolved over time, and the attack chain is very mature and sophisticated, which makes it a good case study for security researchers. This research provides an example of Emotet C2 communication, including C2 server IP selection and data encryption, so we can better understand how Emotet malware utilizes this sophisticated technique to evade security production detection.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are protected from this kind of attack by the following:</p>
<ol>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/subscriptions/threat-prevention">Threat Prevention</a> signatures <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=21201">21201</a>, <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=21185">21185</a> and <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=21167">21167</a> identify HTTP C2 requests attempting to download the new payload and post sensitive info.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire">WildFire</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr">Cortex XDR</a> identify and block Emotet and its droppers.</li>
</ol>
<h4><strong>Indicators of Compromise</strong></h4>
<h6><a id="post-118300-_wye9y8s00tjq"></a>Samples</h6>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2cb81a1a59df4a4fd222fbcb946db3d653185c2e79cf4d3365b430b1988d485f</span></p>
<h6><a id="post-118300-_l3pow32n9xvl"></a>Droppers</h6>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bbb9c1b98ec307a5e84095cf491f7475964a698c90b48a9d43490a05b6ba0a79<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bd1e56637bd0fe213c2c58d6bd4e6e3693416ec2f90ea29f0c68a0b91815d91a</span></p>
<h6><a id="post-118300-_lu3g3imyqim4"></a>URLs</h6>

</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">http://ienglishabc[.]com/cow/JH/<br />

                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/04_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of suspicious registration scam campaigns. Close-up image of a glowing red WiFi connectivity symbol on a textured black surface, symbolizing digital security technology." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/04_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/04_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/04_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/04_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/04_Vulnerabilities_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Network Abuses Leveraging High-Profile Events: Suspicious Domain Registrations and Other Scams:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-12-06T23:00:40+00:00">December 6, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/suspicious-domain-registration-campaigns/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Network Abuses Leveraging High-Profile Events: Suspicious Domain Registrations and Other Scams">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Network Abuses Leveraging High-Profile Events: Suspicious Domain Registrations and Other Scams</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/network-scanning/" title="network scanning" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Network Abuses Leveraging High-Profile Events: Suspicious Domain Registrations and Other Scams:network scanning">Network scanning</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/cybersquatting/" title="cybersquatting" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Network Abuses Leveraging High-Profile Events: Suspicious Domain Registrations and Other Scams:cybersquatting">Cybersquatting</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/chatgpt/" title="ChatGPT" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Network Abuses Leveraging High-Profile Events: Suspicious Domain Registrations and Other Scams:ChatGPT">ChatGPT</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/suspicious-domain-registration-campaigns/" title="Network Abuses Leveraging High-Profile Events: Suspicious Domain Registrations and Other Scams" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Network Abuses Leveraging High-Profile Events: Suspicious Domain Registrations and Other Scams:read now">

                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>

                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/06_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of keylogger malware like KLogEXE and FPSpy.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-09-26T10:00:51+00:00">September 26, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/kimsuky-new-keylogger-backdoor-variant/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/mitre/" title="MITRE" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy:MITRE">MITRE</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/keylogger/" title="Keylogger" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy:Keylogger">Keylogger</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/north-korea/" title="North Korea" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy:North Korea">North Korea</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/kimsuky-new-keylogger-backdoor-variant/" title="Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of SnipBot. Digital abstract background featuring binary code and technology symbols with a blue glow in the shape of a skull." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-09-23T21:00:55+00:00">September 23, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/snipbot-romcom-malware-variant/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/backdoor/" title="backdoor" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant:backdoor">Backdoor</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/romcom/" title="RomCom" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="emotet-command-and-control:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant:RomCom">RomCom</a>

                <div class="card-content__link">

              </div>
            </div>

    </div>

      <div class="bs__progress"><span></span></div>
